body:
My recommendation would be to start interfacing `hmmlearn` and see what we can do.

What is the typology of the algorithms above?
As far as I see, vanilla HMM in its simplest form, is:

* when no part of $X$ has been ever observed:
  * the `transform` part of a transformer (unsupervised), when obtaining $X$ from $Y$ via Viterbi
  * using Baum-Welch is `fit` of the same transformer
* if $X$ has not been observed, predicting $y_{t+1}$ from $y_t$ is forecasting
* if $X$ has been observed, predicting $y_{t+1}$ from $y_t$ is forecasting with an exogeneous variable observed in $X$
* if $X$ has been observed in `fit`, then inferring $X$ on another series or another part of the series is supervised annotation

Anything I´m missing or misclassifying?
I guess: if $X$ is discrete, we can interpret the labelling as segmentation (into contiguous value segments)
and, we can use exogeneous data differently - we can use it as part of $Y$, or as part of $X$

So, in my experience, I think the general interpretation for a typical HMM is that $X$ is usually not observed at all, and I think it is quite common for $X$ to be discrete and to be interpreted as a label. 

Usually in an HMM, you are less interested in predicting $y_{t+1}$ from $y_t$.  This is usually because you already have all the $Y$.  What is the interesting data analysis question here is connecting the observed $Y$ to some $X$ "label" or "hidden state" that you would like to assign to the raw data ($Y$). 

Which is just to say I think the first point you raise is closest to the typical use case of an HMM.  One can think of it as a transformation I suppose!  But one can also call it annotation.  I feel the difference is probably mostly semantics, but I think given the typical use case it might make sense for HMM to live in an annotations folder rather than transformations.

And - why start with interfacing `hmmlearn`? 🙃 I was planning on starting with my own implementation as I mentioned above!  I think there are good reasons for doing this, among them the fact I think interfacing `hmmlearn` is always a good fall back strategy, but I think if we start with it we have little motivation to try any alternatives.  And if we try the alternatives we can test against the working version in `hmmlearn` now!  If its not better, we can stick with what they already have. :)

> What is the interesting data analysis question here is connecting the observed $Y$ to some $X$ "label" or "hidden state" that you would like to assign to the raw data ($Y$). 

I don't agree that this is the *only* interesting question for which one can use HMM. Supervised use is less common, but I think it's quite important in cases where you have some training segmentation labels, in a stream or in a panel setting.
It's just less often presented in random blog posts and online videos (which seemingly almost always talk about the unsupervised batch single-sequence annotation/segmentation application).

> I feel the difference is probably mostly semantics, but I think given the typical use case it might make sense for HMM to live in an annotations folder rather than transformations. 

I think I agree.
The more general question here is, "aren't annotators just a kind of transformers?", design-wise and interface-wise.

>And - why start with interfacing `hmmlearn`? 🙃 I was planning on starting with my own implementation as I mentioned above!

Just a very naive cost-benefit calculation.

`hmmlearn` is an existing solution with a good maintainer base and probably optimized, clean implementations of sub-algorithms.
For achieving any goal related to methodological functionality that already is in `hmmlearn`, it seems interfacing has a lower implementation cost and a lower continuously incurred maintenance cost (and my naive estimate says that difference is substantial, not just "a little bit").

I didn't put "enjoyment from implementing an algorithm" on the benefit side, just to say that explicitly 😄 
You could also put "not invented here" on the other side of the balance... https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Not_invented_here

Personally, I see the added benefit of `sktime` interfaces to expose the "same algorithm" (HMM) with interfaces that lie in different taxonomic areas, e.g., supervised batch segmentation, or unsupervised stream annotation, transformer, etc.

I agree supervised learning of partially observed sequences is also useful/interesting, and not an application of HMMs that I have as much experience in.  In my mind, the unsupervised version makes sense as a place to start still, as I do think it is the expected case, but I certainly think it could be of value to extend to other cases in the future. 

Alright, I can begin with a naive port. I think the disagreement might arise from our estimation of maintenance cost (I am still concerned about relying on a package that the authors have labeled "low maintenance mode"), but perhaps you have a better sense for this. I also think it would be nice to have a single integrated library - as I said - for extensions beyond what `hmmlearn` can do.  But, it certainly would be possible to stick together at least an outward-facing cohesive whole. Lastly, I do think we can build something faster!  But I might be wrong about that.  Perhaps beginning with the naive port is a reasonable place to start.

> Alright, I can begin with a naive port.

I think in the end you should make the call, not me.
You should take into account what people are saying, but in the end you ought to weight the options yourself - it´s your GSoC project!

I also don´t think there is a strongly compelling argument for either option here, there are pros/cons.

issue.title: [ENH] HMM annotation estimator

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
I wanted to share a draft PR of what I have been working on with HMM estimator.
More Details:
- rather than assuming a particular emission distribution function, which I believe is what `hmmlearn` does (ie you can choose to use a Guassian HMM vs a Multinomial Discrete HMM, and you need to either build, or hope an HMM with your emission distribution has already been built), we simply accept a list of functions which behave as pdf and use those to calculate the emission probability. The viterbi algorithm gets to treat those as a black box. - the hope here is that we can add some functionality which automatically generates some nice functions for people if needed (ie give me an n-dimensional gaussian!), but it also gives the flexibility to do more interesting things! - Have an empirical distribution you want to act as a "pdf"? Have some other distribution you are getting from some other system that you would like to use? As long as it can return a valid probability then it *should* work with our HMM estimator, no need to write your own! - I have spent some time optimizing the algorithms with numpy (in particular, the `_calculate_trans_mats` function which is the slowest part), the plan is to push this a bit more and then conduct speed tests between this draft estimator and `hmmlearn`, so we can have a more quantitative comparison of speed. - I implemented a very simple version of a base object, named `SimpleBaseEstimator` and used that here. It is very similar to what Lukasz did in his annotation flavored PR actually, just added in the `get_params()` and `set_params()` functions, which are technically required for it to be a sklearn like estimator. - I am not proposing we replace our Base Object with what I wrote at all, just wanted to see how many of the bells and whistles in Base Estimator I could get away without! Again - just for testing purposes. ### Example of how to use it: ``` from sktime.annotation.hmm import HMM from scipy.stats import norm from numpy import asarray centers = [3.5,-5] sd = [.25 for i in centers] emi_funcs = [(norm.pdf, {'loc': mean, 'scale': sd[ind]}) for ind, mean in enumerate(centers)] test = HMM(emi_funcs, asarray([[0.25,0.75], [0.666, 0.333]])) obs = asarray([3.7,3.2,3.4,3.6,-5.1,-5.2,-4.9]) test.fit(obs) print(test.predict()) ``` <\details> @fkiraly, @lmmentel, @GuzalBulatova

body: This has now been implemented, though I am in the process of further improving the HMM ecosystem in #3099 Progress on improvement can be tracked there, so closing this issue.
